s.text: My European friends always marvel at how hard Americans work, even those who already have plenty of money.
Modern America, however, is a hugely unequal society in which anyone can achieve awesome success, but not many actually do.
Modern America, however, is a hugely unequal society in which anyone can achieve awesome success, but not many actually do.
Modern America, however, is a hugely unequal society in which anyone can achieve awesome success, but not many actually do.
Almost surely not--because in 1950 they were middle class, while in 1996 they would be poor, even if they lived better in material terms.
Almost surely not--because in 1950 they were middle class, while in 1996 they would be poor, even if they lived better in material terms.

Doesn't this mean, then, that having a more or less equal distribution of income makes for a happier society, even if it does not raise anyone's material standard of living ? That is, you can use the fact that people did not feel poor in the 1950s as an argument for a more radical egalitarianism than even most leftists would be willing to espouse.

Families at the 20 th percentile--that is, poorer than 80 percent of the population--may not be legally poor (only about 12 percent of families are officially below the poverty line), but they are likely to regard themselves as very disadvantaged and unsuccessful.
And some economists with no particular ax to grind simply have doubts about the methodology.
So even using the old numbers, most families in 1950 had a material standard of living no better than that of today's poor or near-poor.
So even using the old numbers, most families in 1950 had a material standard of living no better than that of today's poor or near-poor.
So even using the old numbers, most families in 1950 had a material standard of living no better than that of today's poor or near-poor.
So even using the old numbers, most families in 1950 had a material standard of living no better than that of today's poor or near-poor.

If you assume a lower inflation rate and recalculate real incomes back to--say, 1950--you reach what seems to be a crazy conclusion: that in the early 1950s, the era of postwar affluence, most Americans were living below what we now regard as the poverty line.
No--because man does not live by bread, cars, televisions, or even plumbing alone.
No--because man does not live by bread, cars, televisions, or even plumbing alone.
No--because man does not live by bread, cars, televisions, or even plumbing alone.
They live very well in material terms, but they judge themselves relative to their reference group, and so they feel deprived.

We mean that if you could choose between the two material standards of living, other things being the same , you might well prefer the 12 th percentile standard of 1996 to the 50 th percentile standard of 1950.
No--because man does not live by bread, cars, televisions, or even plumbing alone.
Imagine that a mad scientist went back to 1950 and offered to transport the median family to the wondrous world of the 1990s, and to place them at, say, the 25 th percentile level.
(In a land where anyone can become president, anyone who doesn't become president is a failure.)

Take into account improvements in the quality of many other products, and it does not seem at all absurd to say that the material standard of living of that poverty-level family in 1996 is as good as or better than that of the median family in 1950.
